headline: Simple Beef Short Ribs
description: Learn how to cook short ribs with this simple recipe for tender braised short ribs cooked in one pot with onion and garlic in beer and beef broth.

video.description: A low and slow cooking method is the key to these tender, mouth-watering beef short ribs.
video.name: Simple Beef Short Ribs

name: Simple Beef Short Ribs
recipeIngredient: 1 (12 fluid ounce) can or bottle stout beer

recipeInstructions.text: Season ribs with salt and pepper. Dredge in flour until coated; shake off excess.
Heat olive oil and butter in a large skillet or Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Cook ribs until browned, about 5 minutes per side. Remove ribs and set aside.

Add onion and garlic to the skillet; cook and stir until onion is tender, about 5 minutes. Return ribs to the skillet. Pour in beer while scraping the browned bits of food off the bottom of the pan. Pour in beef stock.
Cover and simmer over low heat until ribs are very tender, about 2 hours.

I made one change to the recipe: only in that I doubled it. I don't know if my butcher's cuts on short ribs was wrong, or whether or not that would have made a difference.

That said, I had 2.3 lbs of short ribs in the form of 4 big ribs. I doubled all ingredients and cooked according to directions. In an attempt to avoid crowding the pan, I braised the seasoned/floured ribs in two separate batches. After the first batch (2 big ribs), I contemplated washing out the pan and replacing with new butter/oil. I didn't... cooked next 2 big floured ribs in remaining darkened butter/oil. Prepared everything exactly according to recipe, including buying stout, then doubling ingredients for my extra ribs.

The result: somewhat bitter and burnt-tasting gravy and ribs, with amazing flavors of what might have been. My thoughts are 1) if you're multiplying this recipe, change out your oil/butter before each little batch; 2) the Stout is quite bitter -- I love beer-based marinades and undertones -- but don't multiply the Stout equally by the recipe's ratio. (I used two bottles of Guinness for 2+ pounds of ribs and the bitterness was palpable.)
